Ok so i would like to address my main complaint with this whole series: editing jokes. You need to allow time for the joke to sink in. Don't immediately cut to the next line! It really irks me that you edit like this!

The video claims that it's unlikely that a private meat-inspection company would exist in the absence of the FDA.

This is absurd. Private businesses already perform this function, though the stamp of approval is implicit (as opposed to the explicit FDA seal of approval). Most big restaurant chains have their own inspectors and require that the meat they purchase meets higher standards than the FDA standards.

When you eat meat from a restaurant or supermarket, you are relying on their reputation for selling quality, untainted meat. If a restaurant gets a reputation for selling bad meat, demand for their products would drop dramatically - thereby lowering the price they can charge. When you go to Whole Foods, their good reputation is reflected in the higher price people are willing to pay.

Bureaucratic rule-making is not "democratic." Requiring a common person to read through a complicated law and formally lodge a complaint (bureaucrats seldom, if ever,address one's concern) is in theory and practice far less democratic than having your elective representative have a say in whether said regulation becomes law. These rules are not "laws" unless indirectly or explicitly approved by lawmakers anyway -- if one believes in Article One, Section One, Clause One of the U.S constitution.

bureaucracies and companies are nothing alike despite their organizational structures being similar (its just a result of management efficiency). Companies have to make a profit, corporations have to make their share holders happy (which usually means making a profit) while government bureaucracies have to make their department heads happy and those motivations are as varied as people but profit is almost never a factor. And the overall motivation of an organization determines how it behaves. This underemphasis of profit is sometimes good (FDA, EPA, CIA) and sometimes bad (AHCA, SSA, VA). Basically if money is a major motivator, government regulation is usually terrible (veteran's administration) but if public safety is the major factor, government involvment is awesome, especially in comparison to capitalist alternatives (food & drug administration)

Regulation also clarifies and sets rules in place to enforce legislation. It's not just taking the place of a legislature but putting the framework in place to enforce the laws that Congress passes. There's that joke about how many words are in the US regulations on cabbage sales vs the Gettysburg Address and the Declaration of Independence. That's because all of the enforcement has to take into account a lot more than the legislation does. It's easy to tell someone to do something or not to do something or to say a certain standard must be met but to put penalties in place or framework for how something should be done or what that standard is in the first place (and the scale by which things are measured against) takes a lot more work.

Re: UPS and the postal service. For day to day deliveries, yes UPS is quicker and more efficient, BUT during high traffic times (like Christmas) private delivery companies rely on the USPS to get everything taken care of.
Private companies are concerned with profit and will keep their staff and infrastructure as small as possible to ensure maximum profit. Public agencies (when provided with adequate funding) can be made as large as necessary to fulfill their function whether it be delivering the mail or policing the foster care system.

I think I recall that John Green did one or two videos talking about the work of anarchist anthropologist David Graeber. Well, Graeber has a recent book out called "The Utopia of Rules: On Technology, Stupidity, and the Secret Joys of Bureaucracy." One point Graeber makes is that efforts to decrease government interference in people's lives invariably result in increased bureaucracy. Example: when I was a child, the phone companies were centralized and heavily regulated. For users, it was a simple system. Then the phone companies were deregulated. How many people today would say that dealing with phone company bureaucracies is easier now than it was 40 years ago? No one, of course.

Wouldn't it be great if John Green did a commentary video on bureaucracy as a supplement to this video? Yes. Yes, it would.

Bureaucracies can certainly be dangerous though. In fact the sociologists Max Weber wrote about the dangers of bureaucratic rationality and how it allowed huge injustices to happen, and this was pre holocaust...

The bureaucracy has expanded to meet the needs of the expanding bureaucracy.

One thing I'd add is that complexity often comes from the way bureaucracies have to deal with changing tasks and rules. Many bureaucracies are "system-critical" in a way, meaning that you can't simply shut them down and completely reform them after a period of time - imagine doing that with a school system, for example. Instead, you have to gradually implement the new rules, work out conflicts with the old ones, and replace/remove old rules and tasks so that the transition is much more seamless.
Bureaucracy. It's problematic, but it's the way you use it. Sigh.

"It seems unlikely that a private corporation would spring up to inspect meat." This is a funny example. I have a friend who works at a veterinarian institution and inspects meat and other food before it will be available on the market. This used to be a state institution, but it was bought by a private (US [and I don't live in the US]) corporation and was basically outsourced. It seems kinda worrying, really. But the main point is that there actually seems to be quite a bit of profit to make from food inspection, since everyone who wants to sell his food on the market needs some kind of seal of approval.

When you're done with Federal, I would love to see State then local start.  You can cover the variances in each as you go:

-Governor
-State Legislatures (assembly, state senate)
-County Government (supervisors, the commissions they appoint etc. ex. Los Angeles county is 10 million people - the size of a state - and controlled by 5 supervisors!)
-Courts
-City Governments ( weak/strong mayor, manager-Council, etc.  Plus the commission appointments what are their roles.

-Party structures (National, state, county; delegates, etc)

Hugely misinforming video . The problem with delegated regulations is not constitutional considerations or taking power away from congress . The problem is that these regulators are SOOOOO many. This means that we cannot monitor them effectively or understand them as normal citizens and neither can other institutions (provided they wanted to). Since we cannot monitor them and that we can't do much to them on an individual basis (they are appointed not elected)  they are used by special interests groups to distort competition, government to bully their opponents, control the private sector through taxation/subsidy ( legal-economic blackmail basically) . These people are people , and people put their own interests above others. Why should you give aboslute power to a self-serving being which you cannot effectively monitor.

All the westerners disgruntled about their government and its bureaucracies need to spend time in countries that lack open, democratic governments.  Free Speech in China? Human rights in the Congo? Ha!  Free market in Venezuela?  Yea right.  Democracy is one of the oldest forms of government and the most complex but it is without a doubt the most just and fair.  Its shortcomings are completely overshadowed by its accomplishments.  Go live in Somalia for a year and you would dream of filling out endless papers.  Stop being 'edgy', have some perspective on the world and history, and try to IMPROVE democracy.  After all, 'its the worst system out there, except for all the others.'  This begins by making sure the government is transparent and monied influence removed.

Just because big (vertical structure) or large (horizontal structure) bureaucracy exist, doesn't mean they're good either way. The best, successful, bureaucratic structure is the most simple-designed one. The bigger the bureaucracy, the bigger the chances of trickle-down greed/corruption. After all, this isn't the armed forces. Hell, think for yourself, how do you think tyranny wins everytime, with the 'follow orders, ask questions later' mentality? Big, complicated & complex structures. And governments aren't an excuse. A lot of pencil pushing too...
